results.title: Australian animals dreaming stories
results.brief_description: Aborigines used stories to teach their children about the laws and myths of their land. Pauline McLeod tells five stories about unique Australian animals. Each story is laced with colourful drawings. The stories featured are: ‘The Giant goanna and the black snake’; ‘The Platypus’; ‘How the kangaroo got its pouch’; ‘Why does the kookaburra laugh?’; ‘The Bunyip’.

results.title: The Art of tracking
results.creator_credit: Gary Steer, Tina Dalton, Sky Visuals, Telecast, Discovery Communications, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Wild Visuals
results.brief_description: Although the art of tracking is diminishing worldwide, the skill survives and traditionalists are making efforts to revive it. There are pockets of indigenous people who still rely on their skills to hunt animals for their livelihood. Amongst the Aborigines of arid Australia, the Kalahari Bushmen of Africa and the Inuit of the Arctic, the ability to read the earth survives. This program examines the skills of these people from vastly different environments and is the story of the skill not the kill; the story of “nature detectives”. Awarded the Certificate for creative excellence, USA International Film and Video Festival 1997.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gary Steer, Tina Dalton, Sky Visuals, Telecast, Discovery Communications, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Wild Visuals

results.title: Bridging the gap: the many worlds of Mandawuy
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Rhoda Roberts (Vox Populi), Sonia Voumard (The Age) and Mandawauy Yunupingu (teacher, musican, ambassador and father), on the eve of National Aborigines Day. Mandawuy explores the ways he is bridging the gap between black and white culture through both his band Yothu Yindi, the first aboriginal band to make the charts and to sign with an American record company; and as the Principal of the Yirrkala Community School in North East Arnhem Land, where, as the first aboriginal headmaster, he devised the curriculum mix of aboriginal and western studies known as “Both Ways Education”.

results.title: Mungo lady
results.creator_credit: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
In 1960 the remains of an Aboriginal woman were exhumed at Lake Mungo, NSW by the white anthropologist/archaeologist, Alan Thorne. The woman had been cremated at least 25,000 years ago, providing the first evidence of this practice, and evidence for elaborate funerary customs by Aborigines in pre-historic times. The remains were exhibited around the world, before being returned to the Aborigines in 1990. This program takes a look at this incident from an Aboriginal perspective.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mari Bennett, Rachel Perkins and Blackfella Films

results.title: Australian aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and A I F
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land. This film shows how aborigines live on native animals and plants.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: everything from nature
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Our reliance on manufactured goods is contrasted with the aborigines’ ability to use natural materials around them, which gives rise to a marked respect for their adaptability and sensitivity to the environment. Taked during an expedition by Sydney University to Arnhem Land in 1952.

results.title: Black man's houses
results.creator_credit: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: More than a hundred years after the First Nations peoples of Tasmania were declared “extinct” by white historians, local descendants set out to reclaim the lost graves of their ancestors on Flinders Island in Bass Strait. The neglected burial site at Wybalenna was, in the 1830’s, Australia’s first segregated Reserve, under the directorship of George Augustus Robinson and is now a battleground that divides a community. The film explores the survival and recognition of cultural identities, in the context of a colonialist settler society. Winner Best Australian Film at the Melbourne Film Festival.

results.title: Still on the same way
results.creator_credit: Graham Cavanagh, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Orcalia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
With the help of the First Nations people from Gilwi Community (near Timber Creek, Northern Territory), Bob Ellis of the Sacred Sites Authority and spokesmen from the Northern Land Council, this program explores what sacred sites are, some First Nations concepts of land tenure and how development by white Australia is managed in the Northern Territory through a mandatory consultation process, set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Cavanagh, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Orcalia Productions
